awd_abstract_narration: This research is concerned with investigating the spatio-temporal               patterns of current filaments in an electroluminescent                          semiconductor.  This is an interesting and novel area of                        nonlinear dynamics.  The patterns will be observed with a                       metallurgical microscope topped by a CCD camera.  A frame-grabber               will digitize the output of the CCD camera and load the image                   data into a laboratory micro-computer for subsequent data                       analysis.  The system will be able to record images much faster                 than the expected spiral rotation rate of the filament patterns.                Computer simulations will also be undertaken to understand the                  nonlinear hebahior of these ac thin film electroluminescent                     semiconductor devices.  There is strong theoretical support for                 this type of work at the Institute for Theoretical Physics at                   UCSB.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
